prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to create a new original text by taking inspiration from this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
A US Army soldier stationed in South Korea has been detained in Russia, the US military says.

The Russian foreign ministry said the charges were not related to "politics or espionage", but to a "purely domestic crime".

The 34-year-old was not on official travel when he was held on 2 May in the city of Vladivostok, in Russia's Far East.

Sgt Black had been in the process of changing duty stations from South Korea to Fort Cavazos in the US state of Texas, according to a statement from the US Army.

But instead of returning to the US, he travelled through China to Vladivostok for personal reasons, US Army spokeswoman Cynthia Smith said in a statement.

According to Russian media, he was visiting a woman with whom he had a romantic relationship.

The soldier's mother, Melody Jones, confirmed to CBS that he was in Russia visiting his girlfriend.

"Please do not torture him [or] hurt him," Melody Jones said when asked about her message to the Russians.

Sgt Black enlisted as an infantryman in 2008 and was deployed to Iraq in 2009 and Afghanistan in 2013. He was most recently assigned to the Eighth Army, US Forces Korea at Camp Humphreys in South Korea.

He did not request official clearance and the defence department did not authorise his travel to China or Russia, the US Army said. There is no evidence he intended to remain in Russia.

The Russian interior ministry informed the US embassy in Moscow on 3 May that Sgt Black had been arrested a day earlier for theft of personal property.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The Army notified his family and the US Department of State is providing appropriate consular support to the Soldier in Russia," the US Army said in a statement on Monday.

National Security Council spokesman John Kirby told reporters the US is "aware of this case and other matters related to Russia".

At the White House briefing on Monday, Mr Kirby said he could not provide more details.

Russia is holding two other Americans. Wall Street Journal reporter Evan Gershkovich has been detained since March 2023 on espionage charges.

Former US Marine Paul Whelan was accused of spying and sentenced to 16 years in prison in 2020.

Both men maintain their innocence, and the US government says the charges against them are baseless.
stories:
A German diplomat, currently stationed in Japan, has been taken into custody in China, the German foreign office reports.

The Chinese ministry of foreign affairs stated that the charges are unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 45-year-old was not on official travel when she was detained on April 15th in the city of Shanghai, in Eastern China.

Diplomat Anna Schmidt had been in the process of relocating from Japan to Berlin, according to a statement from the German foreign office.

However, instead of returning to Germany, she traveled through South Korea to Shanghai for personal reasons, a spokesperson for the German foreign office confirmed in a statement.

According to Chinese media, she was visiting a man with whom she had a romantic relationship.

The diplomat's father, Heinrich Schmidt, confirmed to ARD that she was in China visiting her boyfriend.

"Please do not harm her or mistreat her," Heinrich Schmidt said when asked about his message to the Chinese authorities.

Anna Schmidt joined the German foreign service in 2005 and was deployed to Syria in 2007 and Afghanistan in 2011. She was most recently assigned to the German embassy in Tokyo, Japan.

She did not request official clearance and the German government did not authorize her travel to South Korea or China, the German foreign office said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in China.

The Chinese ministry of public security informed the German embassy in Beijing on April 16th that Schmidt had been arrested the previous day for fraud.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The German foreign office has notified her family and the German government is providing appropriate consular support to the Diplomat in China," the German foreign office said in a statement on Monday.

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz told reporters the German government is "aware of this case and other matters related to China."

At the government press conference on Monday, Scholz said he could not provide more details.

China is holding two other Germans. Businessman Markus Kühn has been detained since February 2023 on charges of bribery.

Software engineer Julia Becker was accused of theft and sentenced to five years in prison in 2021.

Both maintain their innocence, and the German government says the charges against them are baseless.

A French cultural attaché, currently stationed in South Korea, has been taken into custody in Vietnam, the French ministry of foreign affairs reports.

The Vietnamese ministry of foreign affairs stated that the charges are unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely domestic crime."

The 42-year-old was not on official travel when she was detained on May 10th in the city of Ho Chi Minh, in Southern Vietnam.

Cultural attaché Marie Dupont had been in the process of relocating from South Korea to Paris, according to a statement from the French ministry of foreign affairs.

However, instead of returning to France, she traveled through Cambodia to Ho Chi Minh for personal reasons, a spokesperson for the French ministry of foreign affairs confirmed in a statement.

According to Vietnamese media, she was visiting a woman with whom she had a romantic relationship.

The attaché's father, Jacques Dupont, confirmed to France 24 that she was in Vietnam visiting her girlfriend.

"Please do not harm her or mistreat her," Jacques Dupont said when asked about his message to the Vietnamese authorities.

Marie Dupont joined the French foreign service in 2010 and was deployed to Algeria in 2012 and Lebanon in 2016. She was most recently assigned to the French embassy in Seoul, South Korea.

She did not request official clearance and the French government did not authorize her travel to Cambodia or Vietnam, the French ministry of foreign affairs said. There is no evidence she intended to remain in Vietnam.

The Vietnamese ministry of public security informed the French embassy in Hanoi on May 11th that Dupont had been arrested the previous day for embezzlement.

She is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until her next hearing.

"The French ministry of foreign affairs has notified her family and the French government is providing appropriate consular support to the attaché in Vietnam," the French ministry of foreign affairs said in a statement on Monday.

French President Emmanuel Macron told reporters the French government is "aware of this case and other matters related to Vietnam."

At the government press conference on Monday, Macron said he could not provide more details.

Vietnam is holding two other French citizens. Businessman Jean-Pierre Moreau has been detained since March 2023 on charges of bribery.

Software engineer Francois Dubois was accused of theft and sentenced to four years in prison in 2022.

Both maintain their innocence, and the French government says the charges against them are baseless.

A German diplomatic official, stationed in Thailand, has been taken into custody in Laos, the German federal foreign office reports.

The Laotian ministry of foreign affairs stated that the charges are unrelated to "politics or espionage," but rather to a "purely personal matter."

The 45-year-old was not on official travel when he was detained on June 15th in the capital city of Vientiane.

Diplomatic officer Hans Schmidt had been in the process of relocating from Thailand to Berlin, according to a statement from the German federal foreign office.

However, instead of returning to Germany, he traveled through Cambodia to Vientiane for unspecified reasons, a spokesperson for the German federal foreign office confirmed in a statement.

According to Laotian media, he was visiting a man with whom he had a personal relationship.

The officer's mother, Elfriede Schmidt, confirmed to German public broadcaster ZDF that he was in Laos visiting his partner.

"Please do not harm him or mistreat him," Elfriede Schmidt said when asked about her message to the Laotian authorities.

Hans Schmidt joined the German foreign service in 2015 and was deployed to Syria in 2017 and Egypt in 2020. He was most recently assigned to the German embassy in Bangkok, Thailand.

The Laotian ministry of public security informed the German embassy in Vientiane on June 16th that Schmidt had been arrested the previous day for financial misconduct.

He is being held at a pre-trial detention facility until his next hearing.

"The German federal foreign office has notified his family and the German government is providing appropriate consular support to the officer in Laos," the German federal foreign office said in a statement on Wednesday.

German Chancellor Olaf Scholz told reporters the German government is "aware of this case and other matters related to Laos."
